ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I would suggest that instead of trying to "fill" class time after the trip, that groups are allowed to use that time to work together on their project.
More readings/background info/speakers frontloaded before the trip would have been more helpful.

This is a unique course because so much of the learning is dependent on the trip to Haiti, (which was a great experience). But because the New Haven component of the course centered on trip preparation and follow-up, the in-class discussions, speakers, etc. felt tacked on.
Best class ever.
The professors and the chance to engage in public health work in a real setting.
The practical experience in working on a project that had immediate impacts.
The trip to Haiti (Which was terrific). The trip is really the heart of the class and is a great opportunity to experience Haitian culture and see how development organizations work on the ground.
The engaging professors and classmates. I liked the readings and the guest speakers that presented throughout the semester.
The trip to Haiti and the opportunity to see agroforestry project in action a developing nation
The trip to Haiti!
Field trip to Haiti.
Practical application of course knowledge in Haiti.
Hands on experience in Haiti, real development work.
The trop

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: It might be better to exclude course auditors and undergraduates in the class in the future. It diminishes the cohesiveness of the group. I understand the potential benefits, but I think it would just work better to have all grad students who are enrolled in the course.While very trivial, the actual classroom was not conducive to such a large class that met for 3 hours. It would be nice to have a bigger room next year.

Would be better to start working on projects as soon as possible- we didn't divide up in earnest until late Jan-Feb. The background info on Haiti was very helpful, but much of that could have been readings done over Christmas break, so that we would have arrived in January prepped and ready - maybe one more class of Haiti background info, then straight into our projects.

Apart from the trip, the class itself should be substantially refined. I imagine that it could go one of two ways:1. It becomes more of a student-led independent study class where students clearly understand that the knowledge, experience, and project that they get out of the class is entirely up to them.OR2. It becomes a much more structured exploration of sustainable development challenges and practices, and the projects have a strong project management leadership and guidance.As it is now, the class feels quite disorganized and thrown together.

There should be more discourse about development theory. There are many faculty at Yale in the Global Affairs and Political Science departments among others who could devote one class our to discussing development as a concept. Reading regarding Haiti's history and present should be assigned over break. The presentation during the first lecture should not be the first time that students learn of the U.S. occupation of Haiti or Toussiant L'Ouverture or voodoo. The Creole class should be offered bootcamp style before the trip. It wasn't regular enough to be effective and instead a certain block of time should be devoted to learning the language in the two weeks before the trip. Bob was a great presence in our class but the irregularity of the Wednesday lessons wasn't efficient.
The curriculum. Either a more guided curriculum on the history of Haiti and development theory or an expectation of more independent study.

I think that the professors could revisit the curriculum and either focus more on the theory aspect, by adding more structure to the reading/discussion/research/writing components of the course, or the practice aspect, by meeting less often as a large group and doing more small-group independent work.
It will be much better if you can invite more expertise in the area of planning and evaluation of projects so that we can learn how we can design our project and evaluate it after the field trip.
More options for types of projects.
A quicker start, things will improve year by year I'm sure.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Gary, Gordon and Emily were always extremely helpful and willing to offer assistance. They are by far the most responsive professors and TA I've had in my masters program.
Always very helpful.
The instructors and TA were all very available and approachable. They are all very nice, relaxed, and easy to talk to.
Emily rocks!
Gordon, Gary and Emily were all very helpful and available.
We had access to many resources we needed, it was great.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This is one of the very few public health courses that provides applied/hands-on experience with public health and the only course in the global health concentration that is actually applied. As someone who wants to work with health systems in developing countries, this was a perfect course for me.
Great intersection of interests for me, as well as a great practical experience course.
This is a useful class because of its hands-on opportunities for learning.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted a course that departed from the highly academic and theoritical approach of YSPH and allowed me to further develop applied skills. I also believed I could contribute to the course projects given my background.
Aligned with my interests. Heard about it when I was still considering programs a year ago, and have been wanting to take it since.

I thought that this course would be really unique as opportunity to work in a large interdisciplinary team focusing on a project together. I was excited to be part of that team and learn about development project man agent and implementation.
I am interested in development and I have always been curious about Haiti's path.
This course seemed like a unique opportunity to engage in practical learning and to work with students from outside my department, who approach sustainable development from different perspectives.

It was a great class to apply the knowledge that we have to real world. As classmates were from various departments, we could get a chance to learn from each other making interdisciplinary approach which is crucial to solve problems.
Want to help Haiti, get more development work, for personal and professional understanding.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: It exceeded my expectations. I thought it would be a good experience but I learned a lot some public health topics that I wasn't very familiar with and the research component of our project allowed me to learn more from fellow students.
Yes - good experience.

No. I am very glad I took the course because of the great experience in Haiti. Aside from that experience, I did not learn about sustainable development or how to effectively design and manage a development project.
Yes.
Yes, overall this course lived up to my expectations.
Yes~!
It exceeded my expectations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, I actually learned a lot more than I expected. I felt like we had a lot of independence to do what we wanted but at the same time, we were fully supported by Gary with our project.
Yes- but much of that was on myself and my group to get a lot out of it.
No. I did take away a reinvigorated desire to travel and work on the community level though.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The disadvantage of my group was one person did not really do anything. An advantage and disadvantage was myself and another group member had vastly different opinions on things which sometimes made things tense but at the same time, both of our approaches were beneficial to the overall project so I think it was a good experience in compromising for both of us.
Learned a lot from the members in my group - brought different experiences and perspectives. Personality challenges can be a disadvantage.
Common advantages and disadvantages apply here. Some group members did more work than others. I wondered if smaller groups of 2-3 would have be better.
Advantages- sharing of skills and talents
I really enjoyed working with my group on our project. This was probably the most rewarding aspect of the course.
Good to work with others to meet challenges, utilize different people's strenghts. Bad if/when group members are dysfunctional.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Start an action plan early on so you can accomplish a lot while you are in Haiti.
You will get out of it as much as you put in. Select a project that you can get your hands around and produce a measurable result in a very limited time.

If the course is structured the same way next year, understand that you are responsible for figuring out what project you want to do in Haiti and taking the initiative to organize it and implement it as if it were an independent study. Get in touch with students from last year's class as soon as possible (or even before you apply for the class) to talk about the what to expect from the class and the organizations you'll be working with in Haiti.
Keep your ten day trip in perspective. You can't fix everything but it is an important step.
prepare early. wear sunscreen and bugspray. read a lot on your own. try to learn some kreyol, if only so you won't be bored at staff and community meetings.
Acknowledge going in that the course centers on the trip to Haiti and be ready to be flexible, especially in terms of the work you do while in Haiti.
From the beginning of semester, think about what kind of project that you can design. Do not be dependent on professor's suggestion only. Be creative but keep in mind what HTRIP and HAS want.
Hit the ground running understandingthe previous years' work, know which group you would like to work with while applying for the course, work hard and play hard in Haiti.
